WB99J8.description:
A series of OGC Interoperability Experiments (IEs) have been working on techniques and technologies for the problem of linking multi-disciplinary and multi-organisation environmental data _without_ transferring data custody or maintenance responsibilities. These IEs, such as the [Second Environmental Linked Features Interoperability Experiment](https://www.opengeospatial.org/projects/initiatives/selfie) (SELFIE), are firmly grounded in W3C and OGC [best practices for spatial data on the web](https://www.w3.org/TR/sdw-bp/). They involve organisations from New Zealand and around the world, trying to find solutions to problems such as: sharing data for transnational groundwater monitoring; linking descriptions of things to related things (e.g. boreholes to aquifers); using [popular vocabularies](https://schema.org/) to semantically describe the properties of things while avoiding misinterpretation; describing links between distributed records for things that change in nature over time and space; for data publishers to associate related information maintained by third parties to their own data; and maybe even the [HTTPRange-14 problem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTTPRange-14). This workshop will first give an overview of **distributed and linked data** concepts: focusing on: why it matters for those responsible for publishing geospatial data; the advantages for those consuming geospatial data; and how search engines get involved. The SELF Interoperability Experiment will be discussed as an example. Then (and for most of the available time) we will work collaboratively to draft the publication of some spatial data using our laptops, taking advantage of these concepts in a way that will not alienate modern web developers or GIS practictioners, i.e. by using JSON-LD, semantic HTML, Web Components, and an implementation of the OGC WFS 3.0 specification for features.

## Details

## Learning outcomes

1. I understand what structured and linked data are.
2. I understand some benefits of structured/linked data.
3. I am aware of the OGC/W3C Best Practices for Spatial Data on the Web.
4. I know how to implement some of the Best Practices.
5. I understand, can re-state, and (perhaps) respond to some of the challenges, limitations, and criticisms of structured/linked data

### Note

Participants will be asked to optionally provide some sample data that may be suitable for publication using linked data concepts. Data from two domains that have a topological relationship are good candidates. If some interesting data are made available with sufficient time, the practical part of the workshop will be geared towards exploring that data. If not, some sample data will be used, at my (the presenter's) discretion.

I do expect you to do some "course reading" to gain a some conceptual understanding. Reading is food for the brain. Here are some foundational documents, in priority order.

- [Spatial Data on the Web Best Practices](https://www.w3.org/TR/sdw-bp/), W3C Working Group Note
- [Linked Data](https://www.w3.org/DesignIssues/LinkedData), Tim Berners-Lee
- [Background to the (first) Environmental Linked Features Interoperability Experiment (ELFIE)](https://www.opengeospatial.org/projects/initiatives/elfie)
- [Creating semantic sites with Web Components and JSON-LD](https://developers.google.com/web/updates/2015/03/creating-semantic-sites-with-web-components-and-jsonld)
- [Building JSON-LD APIs: Best Practices](https://json-ld.org/spec/latest/json-ld-api-best-practices/), W3C Draft Community Group Report
- [GraphDB: Introduction to the Semantic Web](http://graphdb.ontotext.com/documentation/standard/introduction-to-semantic-web.html) (Note: this is more advanced, and largely beyond the scope of the workshop. The intention is to get you thinking wide as well as narrow.)

However, don't stress! There will be no test. If, after doing some reading, you still don't understand the point of any of it, that's fine. There will be plenty of opportunities for discussion.

There *was* (and, to some extent, *still is*) a lot of misplaced hype about Linked Data out there in the untamed wildernesses of the Internet. Don't worry, I haven't drunk of the Semantic Kool Aid. This workshop will be reined in to practical applications rather than pure aspiration. You will come away thinking critically about these Linked Data ideas, perhaps seeded by some contrary opinions and writings by people who have/had their heads firmly screwed on:

- [Two Bit History: Semantic Web](https://twobithistory.org/2018/05/27/semantic-web.html)
- [Cory Doctorow: Metacrap](https://people.well.com/user/doctorow/metacrap.htm)
- [Aaron Swartz: A Programmable Web](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/3f/) (Note: this is a longer read than the others, but lighter and very interesting.)

### Skill level

**Intermediate**

Participants need to understand web development principles and various technologies and standards underpinning the web. If you've done some web development, or if some of these terms are vaguely registering, then we're good to go:

- Semantic HTML
- Linked data, RDF
- JSON (perhaps JSON-LD)
- HTTP REST
- OGC WFS 2 and/or 3
- Vocabularies/ontologies
- SEO
- Web Components

### Things to bring and stuff to do beforehand

Details will be sent out closer to the time, but the basics are:
- A well oiled brain (i.e. please do some reading)
- A laptop with a web browser (Chrome or Firefox preferred)
- Ideally a running instance of https://github.com/geopython/pygeoapi (I'm willing to help you set this up in the days and weeks leading up to the workshop if necessary)
WB99J8.title: An open data SELFIE: how we can improve open data for SEO, interoperability, and the web of data

EMXAWM.description:
CesiumJS is an amazing library for geospatial visualization, but is very bare-metal and you have to build your UI around it. An easier approach is using TerriaJS as your UI to interact with CesiumJS. This workshop will show you how easy that is to do!

## Details

TerriaJS builds upon CesiumJS’ 3D web geospatial visualization, adding a UI for exploring and previewing layers in a catalog, charts and graphs, a “splitter” interactive comparison tool, shareable story building and many other features. In this workshop, you will learn how to build and deploy a rich and compelling TerriaJS application, without writing any code. You will also learn how to extend TerriaJS with custom functionality as your application’s needs grow.

### Skill level

**Beginner/Introductory**

Some experience with JavaScript/NodeJS would be advantageous. Experienced people will not be bored as the sky is the limit.

### Things to bring and stuff to do beforehand

Laptop with a working NodeJS installation and a text editor.
EMXAWM.title: Building your own CesiumJS map, made easy with TerriaJS

NNWXKL.description:
The workshop will include a brief overview of SOS (the OGC's Sensor Observation Service), and NIWA's Sensor Observation Services, to provide context, followed by the hands on workshop.

The workshop will take you through accessing a SOS service (using NIWA's as an example) using R on your own laptop to request specified data from the service, and how you can develop a simple R Shiny web application based on this.

## Details

SOS is becoming the global standard API for sensor (time series) data sharing. NIWA has deployed SOS services providing free public access to monthly climate data summaries, hydrometric and water quality data. The 52 North open source SOS Server application has been used for this. Custom NIWA middleware sits between our underlying databases and the 52 North software, so the system sits alongside our existing databases, simply adding a new mechanism for accessing the data.

NIWA has also developed client tools which users can use to access these services (yes, you can still use CURL if you choose). One is a custom QGIS plugin, which allows users to connect to a SOS service much as they can a WMS or WFS service. The sites of stations providing observations can be shown on the map, and available sensor data graphed and downloaded as required.

The second SOS client is a new SOS4R package, for the R statistical software program. This package provides two sets of capabilities: It can issue SOS requests and return data into local dataframes, but, and more usefully, it also supports a set of abstracted queries, built on top of the native SOS requests, which provides additional requests much more suited to how a user would want to interact with the service - a much more user friendly workflow. 

An R user can use this package to access a SOS service to request data to analyse locally, or as the data access tool for an R Shiny web application allowing others to interact with the service.

In R you will learn how to:

Get a list of sites (stations) which provide data (and which sites provide a specifies reading)
Get a list of what datasets (instrument readings) are available (and filtered by site)
Filter data requests by date/time
Request a dataset for a selected instrument from a site within a specified time period
Plot these data  

In Shiny, you will build a simple web site allowing users to view stations on a map, select a station, a reading , a time extent and download/plot the data.

### Skill level

**Intermediate**

You will need to be very comfortable writing R scripts for all parts of the workshop. Ideally, use R Studio as the IDE, as this works well with R & Shiny and allows you to easily publish your Shiny application on the web on their Shiny server. 

Familiarity with developing Shiny applications and using Leaflet for embedded maps will be useful for the Shiny part of the workshop.

### Things to bring and stuff to do beforehand

Your own laptop with R & RStudio set up for use.
NNWXKL.title: Write your own SOS client for NIWA climate data with R Shiny

W8Y7UU.description:
Pattern matters! What is the most efficient way of allocating a limited amount of water or fertiliser across several paddocks? What is the best spatial land-use configuration to minimise environmental impact in a catchment? More generally, what is the best way of allocating a set of potentially limited resources to a set of locations or areas to get the best bang for your buck? If you are grappling with these types of questions, this workshop is for you! We will guide you step by step through the process of structuring, solving, and mapping spatial optimisation problems using the free and open source spatial modelling and optimisation framework [LUMASS](https://bitbucket.org/landcareresearch/lumass/wiki/Home). Apart from basic GIS skills, we only expect your enthusiasm! Note: Linux or Windows laptop required!

## Details

#### Workshop Content
In this half-day workshop (WS), we provide a practical introduction to spatial optimisation (SO). At the beginning (30 mins.), we will provide a short overview of 

* the types of SO problems you can solve with [LUMASS](https://bitbucket.org/landcareresearch/lumass/wiki/Home)

* what data you need to solve SO problems 

* and how to prepare and structure your data for solving SO problems with [LUMASS](https://bitbucket.org/landcareresearch/lumass/wiki/Home).

In the remainder of the WS (3h), you will be working through the [LUMASS](https://bitbucket.org/landcareresearch/lumass/wiki/Home) [OptimisationHowTo](https://bitbucket.org/landcareresearch/lumass/downloads/OptimisationHowTo_1.2.zip) to replicate the SO scenarios as published in [Herzig et al. (2018)](http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.envsoft.2018.05.005). You can either work completely by yourself and follow the document step by step and ask for assistance if required; or you can follow short demonstrations showing the next set of steps on the screen and then reproduce them on your laptop and then follow the demo of the next set of steps etc. There will be extra tasks for those who complete the [HowTo](https://bitbucket.org/landcareresearch/lumass/downloads/OptimisationHowTo_1.2.zip) before the end of the WS. 
If you are a Linux user, please make sure to download the [source code](https://bitbucket.org/landcareresearch/lumass/src/master/) and [compile](https://bitbucket.org/landcareresearch/lumass/src/master/INSTALL) LUMASS on your machine prior to the workshop (don’t leave it to the last minute)! Please do [get in touch](https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/lumass-users), if you’re hitting trouble! 

#### Material and Links
**Software & Data**

LUMASS: [https://bitbucket.org/landcareresearch/lumass/wiki/Home](https://bitbucket.org/landcareresearch/lumass/wiki/Home) 

OptimistionHowTo: [https://bitbucket.org/landcareresearch/lumass/downloads/OptimisationHowTo_1.2.zip](https://bitbucket.org/landcareresearch/lumass/downloads/OptimisationHowTo_1.2.zip) 

**Background Literature** 

Herzig A, Ausseil A-GE, Dymond JR 2013a. Spatial optimisation of ecosystem services. In: Dymond JR ed. Ecosystem services in New Zealand - conditions and trends. Manaaki Whenua Press, Lincoln, New Zealand. Pp. 511–523. [http://goo.gl/koaEhR](http://goo.gl/koaEhR) 

Herzig A, Nguyen TT, Ausseil A-GE, Maharjan GR, Dymond JR, Arnhold S, Koellner T, Rutledge D, Tenhunen J 2018. Assessing Resource-Use Efficiency of Land Use. Environmental Modelling and Software 107: 34–49. [http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.envsoft.2018.05.005](http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.envsoft.2018.05.005) 

There is more literature referenced in the OptimistionHowTo.

### Skill level

**Beginner/Introductory**

Basic GIS skills required.

### Things to bring and stuff to do beforehand

- bring a 64bit Windows laptop (windows binaries available for download)
- bring Linux laptop with LUMASS pre-installed, i.e. download and compilation by attendee required
W8Y7UU.title: Spatial Optimisation 101

SNN83F.description:
Do you want to create minimal nice looking maps without all the overhead of a typical mapping library? Are you bothered of all the extra stuff that obstructs the display of your geospatial data?
Using d3 is a great way to create minimal nice looking maps and this workshop will teach you the essentials you need to know.

## Details

The revised workshop is a hands-on, bring your device type of workshop where I teach participants with projects and exercises on how to create maps with d3.
The workshop showcases the essential features of d3 for quickly creating geospatial data visualizations, and the result is a choropleth map that every participant creates on their own and takes home.

Mapping in the browser is a hot topic, and there are plenty of tools and ways to visualize data. The power of d3 is the interactivity and closeness to the data.
Creating minimal looking maps with or without basemaps and still have interactivity is a great asset of d3.

The goal of the session is to provide the participants with the tools and the knowledge to create interactive choropleth maps from geo- and topojson files. Along the way, the base concepts of d3 will be covered as well.

Participants should know Javascript and should have worked with a mapping library such as OpenLayers, Mapbox GL, or Leaflet before.

Learnings: When is d3 the right tool for creating a map and the best approach to create a map with d3.

The topics include:

- Creating a simple map from both geojson and topojson
- Changing the projection of the map
- Creating a choropleth map
- Updating the map
- Adding interaction to the map
- Creating a tooltip
- Create a bubble map



**Learnings**: When is d3 the right tool for creating a map and the best approach to create a map with d3.

**What to take home**: Basic d3 Map with your data or an open dataset. 

**Required facilitations**: Local network, participants laptops, web browser

**Knowledge required**: medium-level Javascript knowledge, basic HTML, basic CSS

### Skill level

**Intermediate**

medium-level Javascript knowledge, basic HTML, basic CSS

### Things to bring and stuff to do beforehand

Laptop
SNN83F.title: Geospatial data visualization with d3

JX7NNK.description:
Digital Earth Australia have been working with FrontierSI to prepare a sandbox environment where you can use the Open Data Cube to explore over thirty years of Earth observation data covering the Australian continent. This workshop will introduce you to the Open Data Cube, the Jupyter data science environment, and analysis ready data in a live coding environment, the DEA Sandbox.

## Details

The Open Data Cube (ODC) is a collaborative effort to develop software and a community of users around a common goal of increasing the ease of access to Earth observation data. The increase in the number of Earth observing satellites over the past few years, coupled with new open data policies and new storage formats like Cloud Optimised GeoTIFF, means that there is a need for a standard way to plug in to this data and enable analysis processes. The ODC provides this way. 

This workshop will introduce you to Digital Earth Australia’s (DEA) implementation of the ODC, the DEA Sandbox, and through the use of the Sandbox, you’ll work through a suite of examples that show you what the ODC can do and what data DEA make available for Australia. This workshop will cover the following topics:
* What is analysis ready data
* What is Jupyter and how can I use it 
* Using simple Jupyter apps to explore data 
* Do-it-yourself example implementing NDVI from scratch
* Advanced example using Landsat 8 optical data to identify coastlines over time 
* Advanced example using Sentinel 1 radar data to identify water.

### Skill level

**Intermediate**

Some Python programming experience is required as this workshop involves some hands-on coding.

### Things to bring and stuff to do beforehand

Attendees are required to bring a laptop with a modern web browser, preferably Google Chrome.

We require Internet access for the workshop participants.
JX7NNK.title: The Open Data Cube Masterclass

SQYRSK.description:
Everyone loves pretty maps! Regardless of your field, background, or software application of choice, we're all striving to make the most beautiful maps we can (as quickly as we can!). During this workshop I'll be showcasing a ton of cartographic tips and tricks to help make your maps prettier.

We’ll be leveraging QGIS’ rich cartographic features to explore how you can improve your maps through refined color choices, data-driven symbology, taming the labeling engine, and crafting automated print layouts. We'll also be exploring cartographic best-practice and how to follow this using FOSS4G software. No coding or development experience is required, and we'll be teaching techniques of value to both new and experienced users alike!

(Note that while we'll be using QGIS as the cartographic application of choice, many of the techniques demonstrated during this workshop can be transposed to other desktop GIS applications or web mapping platforms.)

## Details

Everyone loves pretty maps! Regardless of your field, background, or software application of choice, we're all striving to make the most beautiful maps we can (as quickly as we can!). During this workshop I'll be showcasing a ton of cartographic tips and tricks to help make your maps prettier.

We’ll be leveraging QGIS’ rich cartographic features to explore how you can improve your maps through refined color choices, data-driven symbology, taming the labeling engine, and crafting automated print layouts. We'll also be exploring cartographic best-practice and how to follow this using FOSS4G software. No coding or development experience is required, and we'll be teaching techniques of value to both new and experienced users alike!

(Note that while we'll be using QGIS as the cartographic application of choice, many of the techniques demonstrated during this workshop can be transposed to other desktop GIS applications or web mapping platforms.)

This workshop is being run by Nyall Dawson (from North Road Consulting), who is a frequent contributor to the QGIS desktop application and has been crafting maps for the last 10 years.

### Skill level

**Intermediate**

No prerequisite skills required! But don't misinterpret this as a "beginner" workshop -- even advanced users will gain new insights and skills...

### Things to bring and stuff to do beforehand

Please bring your own laptop with the latest QGIS release installed. Also bring any example maps you think are great, and would love to learn how to reconstruct!
SQYRSK.title: Creating beautiful maps quickly!

J79QZN.description:
3geonames.org aggregates a lot of open data from a variety of sources to provide a fast, free reverse geocoder for every location on the globe using a data structure based on the Hilbert curve. Also, due to its design, api.3geonames.org runs on a server (or any cheap smartphone) with only 1GB of RAM and 1 Cpu with a theoretical throughput of over 500 requests per second. This talk expands on the use case and the techniques used to solve the problem and show participants how to use the 3geonames API as a location context platform to build location-based apps.

## Details

[3geonames.org](https://3geonames.org) started out as a project to provide an alternative open location code. It currently does so, mapping latitude, longitude, elevation into three geonames compiled from geonames.org - using techniques based on the Hilbert curve.

The project has lately pivoted into other practical applications of location encoding, such as reverse geocoding - the process of obtaining location information such as city names, timezone, elevation, admin polygons, points of interest, etc from an input point. 

A space fitting curve such as the Hilbert curve is quite suitable for indexing multidimensional data for fast access - as I will show by indexing millions of open-source data points for reverse geocoding. You can also extend the API by adding your own geofences for your location-aware apps. I'll show how you can use the API to quickly build location features for apps by building a quick mockup for a practical location encoding problem.

I'll also show about how you can test and preview the upcoming features of [3geonames API](https://3geonames.org/api), such as 3D geofences, reverse 3D geocoding, voice geocoding and crowdsourced geo-location encoding.

### Skill level

**Beginner/Introductory**

Basic scripting knowledge is a plus but not required.

### Things to bring and stuff to do beforehand

A laptop with their favorite scripting language interpreter for building some sample real-world apps based on this API.
J79QZN.title: Building location-aware apps with 3geonames.org - A very fast reverse geocoder for any location on land and water.

S7PXRA.description:
Mapbox GL JS is a free and open source JavaScript library for interactive, customisable vector maps on the web.

## Details

This workshop will teach you how to build your own interactive and customisable vector maps for the web.

Covering core concepts of modern vector maps and building with Mapbox GL JS including:
- Layers
- Sources
- Mapbox GL Style Spec
- Controls
- Markers
- Popups
- Expressions
- Feature States
- Custom Layers

Beyond the core concepts you'll learn some useful tips and tricks to deal with common scenarios.

Ideally participants would have at least basic JavaScript knowledge, but no prior mapping knowledge required.

### Skill level

**Intermediate**

Basic or higher JavaScript knowledge is strongly recommended. If you know what variables, functions, JSON and HTML are you should be fine.

No prior Mapbox GL JS experience required, but even if you've done a little bit with Mapbox before you'll hopefully still get value from the depth of topics which we'll cover.

### Things to bring and stuff to do beforehand

A laptop
S7PXRA.title: Mapbox GL JS

CZVKRS.description:
Do you want to make a beautiful map that you can publish on your own website? All without having to worry about all that techie hosting/databases/cloud stuff that can just be overwhelming?

Yes? Then this workshop is for you! You’ll find out what’s involved in creating your own self-hosted web map. (Without needing years of experience in software development to understand the process.)

## Details

You may have heard about new technologies like vector tiles, that let you make huge and complex data available as a web map, or those cloud services run by Amazon, or looked at the amazing services from Mapbox, but been nervous about what it would cost if your map suddenly got a lot of attention. Well, you don’t need any of those!

We’ll be using vector tiles to build a web map that you can upload to any web hosting service – from the cheapest shared web host to a WordPress site. No complex pay-per-month cloud services, no spatial web servers, and no databases - just a simple map that’s yours to own.

This workshop isn’t about learning to code, learning QGIS, or learning about data – it’s about putting those components together to achieve something bigger. We'll be walking you through the whole process of making the technology work for you step-by-step.

First, we'll take open data published by the New Zealand government and use it to create vector tiles. (Vector tiles are a neat new way to package up data in a way that’s ideally suited to web maps.) Then we’ll use Mapbox Studio to design a snazzy looking map with our data. Finally, we'll upload it to your very own website and share it with the world.

The maps we’ll be creating are ideal for those times you want to make a map that you can just upload and forget about. They're perfect for student projects, company websites, or for cartographers and designers who want to craft beautiful customised maps that are easy to hand over to clients.

The workshop will provide you with the knowledge you need to get started, but you're free to deviate from the examples that we provide as you grow more confident and start to explore the tools available to you.

Looking forward to seeing your creations!

Image: NZ Topo50 Map series from LINZ. Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International license.

### Skill level

**Beginner/Introductory**

Audience: Beginner to intermediate-level.

Some basic programming knowledge may be advantageous, but not essential.

### Things to bring and stuff to do beforehand

Please bring a laptop. Sorry, but tablets won't do :)

The software we'll be using will run on Windows, macOS, or Linux.

Further information on the software you'll need to have installed before the workshop will be circulated before the conference.
CZVKRS.title: Keeping it simple: Building a web map you can host virtually anywhere

RKAAHQ.description:
Static or interactive maps can reveal useful patterns and insights. For example, layering accident locations on a basemap can highlight hotspots of poor road safety. These simple data overlays can be extended to an integrated analysis with the road network for deeper insight - like accident hotspots on road segments that bottleneck commuter flows. As denizens of a city we primarily interact with the built urban environment via its streets, roads and paths. Hence, intuitive questions of the 'Urban Experience' must involve the geospatial road network.

## Details

In this workshop, we'll use Python and the packages, osmnx and pandana, to characterise Wellington: the cool little capital of New Zealand with a unique topography. Using omsnx, pandana and data of the built environment (from OpenStreetMap and Wellington City Council open data), we can quantify how Wellington functions as a city.

Foundational topics include:

- Handling geospatial data with geopandas
- Getting street networks with osmnx
- Routing with network algorithms
- Calculating flows from routes

Urban analysis topics include:

- Analysing street morphology and topography with osmnx
- Accessibility analysis with pandana
- Catchment areas of amenities with pandana

### Skill level

**Intermediate**

Participants will need to have some experience with Python programming to finish the exercises. An early intermediate level will be sufficient as the analysis will not involve heavy programming.

### Things to bring and stuff to do beforehand

Attendees must bring their own laptops with Python 3, geopandas, osmnx and pandana installed. They will also need matlplotlib and basemap. A full list of packages will be provided closer to the workshop date. Attendees will also need a Google Elevation API key. Again, further details will be sent out later.
RKAAHQ.title: Analysing geospatial connectivity to understand a city

QSBVAQ.description:
The graphical modeller is a powerful component that we can use to define a workflow and run a chain of algorithms (a processing model).

A normal session with the processing framework tools includes more than running a single algorithm. Usually several of them are run to obtain a result, and the outputs of some of those algorithms are used as input for some of the other ones.

Using the graphical modeller, that workflow can be put into a processing model, which will run all the necessary algorithms in a single run, thus simplifying the whole process and automating it.

## Details

In this workshop we will create a processing model in the graphical modeller that displays buildings affected by some event within a distance from an event location.  

The affected buildings are determined by 
* Clicking a point on the map canvas to define an event location,
* travelling a distance along the road network from the event location, 
* buffering the travel distance to intersect land parcels, 
* extracting building footprints that that intersect the land parcels.

The Inputs
* Event location point chosen on the Map Canvas
* Road network layer
* Travel distance value
* Travel distance buffer value
* Land parcel layer
* Building footprints layer

The outputs
* Event location point layer
* Affected road network line layer
* Travel distance buffer polygon layer
* Affected buildings polygon layer

### Skill level

**Advanced**

Intermediate level QGIS minimum

### Things to bring and stuff to do beforehand

Laptop loaded with latest QGIS release.
QSBVAQ.title: QGIS Processing Models and the Graphical Modeller

SPGUQV.description:
This hands-on workshop covers the use of [PyGMT](https://github.com/GenericMappingTools/pygmt) to analyze geospatial data and produce publication quality figures and animations in an interactive [Jupyter](https://jupyter.org/) lab environment. After a quick guide to launching up PyGMT on your computer, we will start with the basics of making your first map with PyGMT and explore some different customizations such as fancy projection systems and colormaps. Next we will teach you how to load in CSV point and GeoTIFF/NetCDF grid datasets using [pandas](https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas) and [xarray](https://github.com/pydata/xarray), and have PyGMT perform more advanced geoprocessing workflows such as sampling, filtering and interpolation on them. Finally, we will step you through making 3D perspective plots and animations of your final results!

## Details

From processing raster grids and vector data (points, lines, polygons) to creating visually appealing maps in different projection systems, the [Generic Mapping Tools (GMT)](https://github.com/GenericMappingTools/gmt/) is a swiss army knife collection of open source tools used by Earth, Ocean and Planetary scientists worldwide. [PyGMT](https://github.com/GenericMappingTools/pygmt) is a more user-friendly, Pythonic interface to GMT 6's modern execution mode that integrates well with the [PyData](https://pydata.org/) stack. This includes reading [numpy](https://github.com/numpy/numpy) arrays, [pandas](https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas) tables and [xarray](https://github.com/pydata/xarray) grids, plus support for rich display in interactive [Jupyter](https://jupyter.org/) notebook environments. It is also a powerful library used for processing geospatial and geophysical datasets, including operations like sampling, filtering, interpolation and so on.

### Skill level

**Intermediate**

This workshop is intended for people with some previous Python programming/GMT experience. We invite students and geoscientists working on any geo related fields (e.g. Earth Observation, Geophysical, Marine, Magnetic, Gravity, Planetary, etc) to join. We also welcome seasoned GMT veterans who would like to find out how the Python interface works with GMT 6's modern execution mode and people from the geospatial industry with some Python programming experience that would like to get to know what PyGMT can do for parts of their geoprocessing workflow.

### Things to bring and stuff to do beforehand

A github repository containing jupyter notebooks for the workshop will be set up prior to the workshop. Users should only need to have a laptop with a modern browser that can launch an online [Pangeo Binder](https://binder.pangeo.io/) link/[Google Colaboratory](https://colab.research.google.com/) Jupyter computing environment. This should give everyone a relatively consistent experience.
SPGUQV.title: PyGMT for geoscientists - A PyData compatible package for analyzing and plotting time-series and gridded data

7AHC8Q.description:
What does it look like to work in the core C++ _(and Python, and Perl, and even a little bit of raw C)_ logic of QGIS?  
This workshop will cover an intro into building, understanding, and navigating the core QGIS codebase.   

This workshop will be an attempt to help demystify the QGIS core codebase in order to help ease you into QGIS core development.   There is no requirement to leave the workshop understanding every bit of the QGIS codebase as there is a lot and even some of the current core developers don't understand it all :)

## Details

What does it look like to work in the core C++ _(and Python, and Perl, and even a little bit of raw C)_ logic of QGIS?  
This workshop will cover an intro into building, understanding, and navigating the core QGIS codebase.   

This workshop will be an attempt to help demystify the QGIS core codebase in order to help ease you into QGIS core development.   There is no requirement to leave the workshop understanding every bit of the QGIS codebase as there is a lot and even some of the current core developers don't understand it all :) 

The main takeaways from this workshop is understanding the workflows core developers normally take in order to land a bug or feature into the next release.  Simply understanding where things are and how to navigate the code can lead to openings in fixing bugs or adding new features.  Starting simple and working your way up very much applies to QGIS.

Topics we will try to cover in the workshop are:

- Build setup
- Qt Creator
- Understanding where the code lives
- Navigate the code
- How the Python bindings are made (SIP - Here be dragons)
- Unit tests
- PR/Merge process (for features and bugs)
- 
Knowing C++ will help you in advance but it's not a requirement of this workshop so don't be put off by that.  There is more to the QGIS code base then a pile of C++ and this workshop will give you exposer to those other areas as well.

### Skill level

**Intermediate**

No skill level is required however as this will deep dive into some of the core C++ code logic attendees should be at least be comfortable with knowing that is going to happen and not being able to understand what is going on 100% of the time.

Past C++ experience will help but is not a requirement.

### Things to bring and stuff to do beforehand

Laptop
7AHC8Q.title: Demystifying QGIS core development

Edwin Liava'a.bio:
Edwin has a personal philosophy - "I innovate and provide solutions, not problems".

With over 20 years of experience working in the Pacific Islands region providing contextualized solutions and capacity building in ICT, his passion is driven by harnessing inter-cultural competencies. These competencies go well beyond technical knowledge and leadership qualities, because each Pacific Island has its own unique local context. Also important is the ability to possess a high level of cultural flexibility and tolerance to be neutral when it comes to discussions that might overlap from being politically correct to being in-correct.

Edwin believes that "The best idea should always win and we hire smart people to tell us what to do, not for us to tell them what to do."
Edwin Liava'a.name: Edwin Liava'a
Edwin Liava'a.shortBio: Edwin has over 20 years of experience working in the Pacific Islands region providing contextualized solutions and capacity building in ICT.
Edwin Liava'a.title: CEO

Dr. Kate Crawford.bio:
After successful careers as a pharmacist, a teacher (K-12), an academic, international researcher and software developer, Kate is now the director of a consultancy company Eviva Pty Ltd, an Honorary Principle Research Fellow at the University of Wollongong and an advisor to the Spatial Industry Business Association in Australia. She has experience in cross cultural settings including as a founder of the ANTEP program at Ernabella, South Australia and in Indigenous business development and program development in collaboration with communities.

Major projects include national programs to engage students and their parents in emerging Citizen Science projects, Community programs to connect older people with their community via digital technologies (Living Connect) in Illawarra region, Research with the University of Wollongong and Defence Science and Technology Organisation to enable more independent self-directed collaboration in the field (ARC Discovery Program). After much experience in early IT design and development, networked interactive communication technologies and related social innovation and problem solving, her current interest is the use of spatial technologies as tools in different cultures and to enable more sustainable practices for land and water management.
Dr. Kate Crawford.name: Dr. Kate Crawford
Dr. Kate Crawford.shortBio: After much experience in early IT design and development, networked interactive communication technologies and related social innovation and problem solving, her current interest is the use of spatial technologies as tools in different cultures and to enable more sustainable practices for land and water management.
Dr. Kate Crawford.title: Owner Director

Miriam Gonzalez.bio:
Miriam is co-founder of projects based in mobile applications and location intelligence technologies and the Geochicas initiative where she promotes more women participation and knowledge sharing in geospatial spaces.

For the past few years Miriam has been highly involved in promoting OpenStreetMap and Humanitarian OpenStreetMap (HOTOSM), increasing the participation of the community in Mexico and LatAm by giving workshops, conferences and coordinating efforts among key players in open data.

Currently she is involved in open data, autonomous vehicles, partnerships and data analysis initiatives.
Miriam Gonzalez.name: Miriam Gonzalez
Miriam Gonzalez.shortBio: Miriam is co-founder of projects based in mobile applications and location intelligence technologies and the Geochicas initiative.
Miriam Gonzalez.title: CEO / Co-Founder

Lyzi Diamond.bio:
Lyzi Diamond is a geographer/teacher/programmer living in New York City. In 2013 she co-founded Maptime, an organization of 80+ location-based community groups across the world focused on teaching each other about maps and geospatial technology.

She is currently a Developer Advocate at Glitch, a platform for building full-stack web applications in the browser. She cares a lot about map projections and probably wants to talk to you about most cool things!
Lyzi Diamond.name: Lyzi Diamond
Lyzi Diamond.shortBio: Lyzi Diamond is a geographer/teacher/programmer living in New York City. In 2013 she co-founded Maptime, an organization of 80+ location-based community groups across the world.
Lyzi Diamond.title: Developer Advocate

KB7F3Z.name: Wei Ji Leong
KB7F3Z.bio: Geospatial Data Scientist/[PhD Student in Glaciology](https://www.victoria.ac.nz/antarctic/study/profiles/wei-ji-leong) at the [Antarctic Research Centre](https://www.victoria.ac.nz/antarctic) in [Victoria University of Wellington](https://www.victoria.ac.nz). Interested in earth observation data and deep learning, currently building Convolutional Neural Network architectures for better mapping the bedrock elevation of Antarctica. Also a demonstrator for the introductory GIS course at VUW, and have worked previously as a Spatial Data Analyst at [e-Spatial](https://www.e-spatial.co.nz/) and [LINZ](https://www.linz.govt.nz/). Check out my profile on [Github](https://github.com/weiji14/) and [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/wjleong14).
KB7F3Z.shortBio: Geospatial Data Scientist/[PhD Student in Glaciology](https://www.victoria.ac.nz/antarctic/study/profiles/wei-ji-leong) at the [Antarctic Research Centre](https://www.victoria.ac.nz/antarctic) in [Victoria University of Wellington](https://www.victoria.ac.nz). Interested in earth observation data and deep learning, currently building Convolutional Neural Network architectures for better mapping the bedrock elevation of Antarctica. Also a demonstrator for the introductory GIS course at VUW, and have worked previously as a Spatial Data Analyst at [e-Spatial](https://www.e-spatial.co.nz/) and [LINZ](https://www.linz.govt.nz/). Check out my profile on [Github](https://github.com/weiji14/) and [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/wjleong14).

RUKHTS.name: Nathan Woodrow
RUKHTS.bio: Nathan is a core QGIS developer and software developer for Chartis Technology. He has been involved as a developer in the QGIS project since 2011 (wow old), but still loves it the same if not more since he has seen to grow into what it is.
RUKHTS.shortBio: Nathan is a core QGIS developer and software developer for Chartis Technology. He has been involved as a developer in the QGIS project since 2011 (wow old), but still loves it the same if not more since he has seen to grow into what it is.

BANWRY.name: Shrividya Ravi
BANWRY.bio: I am a Data Scientist who has recently discovered a passion for urban analysis and development. I believe that open data and FOSS4G gives citizens an incredible opportunity to understand how their city works and investigate avenues / causes of particular interest to them.
BANWRY.shortBio: I am a Data Scientist who has recently discovered a passion for urban analysis and development. I believe that open data and FOSS4G gives citizens an incredible opportunity to understand how their city works and investigate avenues / causes of particular interest to them.
BANWRY.title: Senior Data Analyst

9S7T9U.name: Keith Moss
9S7T9U.bio:
I’m a data geek, occasional software engineer, and a bit of geospatial tragic. I’ve built more web mapping applications than I care to remember - for everything from delivering satellite data in support of bushfires and floods to mapping sausage sizzles and orangutans.

For a living, I work for the Western Australian government where I run the state’s open data team and work to convince public servants of the benefits of making data open, machine-readable, and API-enabled. I’m passionate about applying the user experience principles from our digital world to the broader work of government – building better public services by understanding needs through user research, data-driven insights, and co-design of services.

But most of all, I love helping people to learn, understand, and use data and technology and seeing those “Ah-ha!” moments when they get it.
9S7T9U.shortBio:
I’m a data geek, occasional software engineer, and a bit of geospatial tragic. I’ve built more web mapping applications than I care to remember - for everything from delivering satellite data in support of bushfires and floods to mapping sausage sizzles and orangutans.

For a living, I work for the Western Australian government where I run the state’s open data team and work to convince public servants of the benefits of making data open, machine-readable, and API-enabled. I’m passionate about applying the user experience principles from our digital world to the broader work of government – building better public services by understanding needs through user research, data-driven insights, and co-design of services.

But most of all, I love helping people to learn, understand, and use data and technology and seeing those “Ah-ha!” moments when they get it.

7CBZC8.name: Alex Herzig
7CBZC8.bio:
I am a [Geospatial Modeller](https://nz.linkedin.com/in/alexander-herzig-919a835) at [Manaaki Whenua](https://www.landcareresearch.co.nz/about/people/staff-details?id=aGVyemlnYQ==) and passionate about modelling and software. As part of my work, I am developing the free and open source spatial modelling and optimisation framework [LUMASS](https://bitbucket.org/landcareresearch/lumass/wiki/Home). 
Before I moved to New Zealand, I worked as a lecturer and research assistant in the Landscape Ecology and Geoinformation group at the Department of Geography at the Christian-Albrechts-Universitaet in Kiel, Germany.
7CBZC8.shortBio:
I am a [Geospatial Modeller](https://nz.linkedin.com/in/alexander-herzig-919a835) at [Manaaki Whenua](https://www.landcareresearch.co.nz/about/people/staff-details?id=aGVyemlnYQ==) and passionate about modelling and software. As part of my work, I am developing the free and open source spatial modelling and optimisation framework [LUMASS](https://bitbucket.org/landcareresearch/lumass/wiki/Home). 
Before I moved to New Zealand, I worked as a lecturer and research assistant in the Landscape Ecology and Geoinformation group at the Department of Geography at the Christian-Albrechts-Universitaet in Kiel, Germany.
7CBZC8.title: Geospatial Modeller

8A7KCW.name: Andrew Harvey
8A7KCW.bio:
Andrew runs a Sydney based geospatial consulting firm Alantgeo, building out Mapbox, Mapillary and OpenStreetMap solutions for commercial and government customers.

A frequent contributor to the open source Mapbox GL JS project, heavy OpenStreetMap contributor and various other open source and open data projects.

Co-creator of the bushwalking website beyondtracks.com.
8A7KCW.shortBio:
Andrew runs a Sydney based geospatial consulting firm Alantgeo, building out Mapbox, Mapillary and OpenStreetMap solutions for commercial and government customers.

A frequent contributor to the open source Mapbox GL JS project, heavy OpenStreetMap contributor and various other open source and open data projects.

Co-creator of the bushwalking website beyondtracks.com.
8A7KCW.title: CEO

D8HTJL.name: Ervin Ruci
D8HTJL.bio:
I've been solving problems for my own enjoyment and profit since 2005 when I quit my last day job (as a software developer)
The main areas I like to work on are Computational Geometry and NLP. Some of the problems I've tackled over the years in these application domains have become successful companies with exactly one employee - me.

GHSHKM.name: Nyall Dawson
GHSHKM.bio:
Nyall has been a core developer with the QGIS project since 2013. During this time he has contributed over 5000 commits to the project, and today is one of the most active developers on the project. Nyall’s contributions to QGIS cover a wide range of areas – from improvements to the map rendering and symbology engines, enhancements to labeling and print layout functionality, right through to optimisations of the underlying spatial processing algorithms utilised by QGIS.

Nyall is the proprietor and lead developer at North Road Consulting, an Australian based spatial development consultancy which predominantly utilises international co-funding and crowd funding campaigns to finance development into open source GIS applications.
GHSHKM.shortBio:
Nyall has been a core developer with the QGIS project since 2013. During this time he has contributed over 5000 commits to the project, and today is one of the most active developers on the project. Nyall’s contributions to QGIS cover a wide range of areas – from improvements to the map rendering and symbology engines, enhancements to labeling and print layout functionality, right through to optimisations of the underlying spatial processing algorithms utilised by QGIS.

Nyall is the proprietor and lead developer at North Road Consulting, an Australian based spatial development consultancy which predominantly utilises international co-funding and crowd funding campaigns to finance development into open source GIS applications.
GHSHKM.title: QGIS Core Developer, Proprietor

XPVGDM.name: Andy McKenzie
XPVGDM.bio: I work in the Population Modelling Group at NIWA (Wellington). In our work we use the R programming language extensively, and at the NIWA Wellington site I run the R users group.
XPVGDM.shortBio: I work in the Population Modelling Group at NIWA (Wellington). In our work we use the R programming language extensively, and at the NIWA Wellington site I run the R users group.

SYCPXT.name: Brent Wood
SYCPXT.bio: I have worked at NIWA (or its predecessors) for over 40 years. I have been an enthusiastic user of open source and supporter of open standards and open data since the 1980's. Starting computing with CPM/80 on 4Mhz Z80 cpu's, I have seen a few changes over the years! I was a founder of the Wellington Amstrad User Group and WellyLUG, ran a public FIDOnet & USEnet BBS before the internet came along, and was an NZOSS council member for several years. I am a Charter Member of OSGEO and the NIWA representative in OGC. I have attended and presented at most FOSS4G conferences in the last 10 years, as well as at the Wellington Postgres Users Group and, more recently, WOSSAT.  in 2016 I won the People's Choice NZOSA for services to Geospatial Open Source in New Zealand. I am passionate about Open Source, Open Data and Open Standards and am fortunate to have an employer who also values these and supports my efforts in this area.
SYCPXT.shortBio: I have worked at NIWA (or its predecessors) for over 40 years. I have been an enthusiastic user of open source and supporter of open standards and open data since the 1980's. Starting computing with CPM/80 on 4Mhz Z80 cpu's, I have seen a few changes over the years! I was a founder of the Wellington Amstrad User Group and WellyLUG, ran a public FIDOnet & USEnet BBS before the internet came along, and was an NZOSS council member for several years. I am a Charter Member of OSGEO and the NIWA representative in OGC. I have attended and presented at most FOSS4G conferences in the last 10 years, as well as at the Wellington Postgres Users Group and, more recently, WOSSAT.  in 2016 I won the People's Choice NZOSA for services to Geospatial Open Source in New Zealand. I am passionate about Open Source, Open Data and Open Standards and am fortunate to have an employer who also values these and supports my efforts in this area.
SYCPXT.title: Programme leader for information delivery

TJ3SDB.name: Mila Frerichs
TJ3SDB.bio: I'm a Data Visualization consultant working with civic advocacy groups and social organizations.
TJ3SDB.shortBio: I'm a Data Visualization consultant working with civic advocacy groups and social organizations.
TJ3SDB.title: Founder/CEO

STEC7C.name: Alex Leith
STEC7C.bio: Alex is a certified spatial professional with extensive experience in software development, DevOps and project management. Alex has spent time volunteering for GovHack and GeoRabble and is one of a handful of GeoHipster interviewers, which means he is in touch with a broad community of hip geo-folk. When not writing code, or at least talking to people about writing code, he likes a great craft beer (currently seeking out the best XPA) or whisky (with a preference for those from Islay). Alex is a technical leader at Geoscience Australia, working with a team of developers on software that enables people to work with Earth observation data.

Alex has spent time volunteering for GovHack and GeoRabble and is one of a handful of GeoHipster interviewers, which means he is in touch with a broad community of hip geo-folk. When not writing code, or at least talking to people about writing code, he likes a great craft beer (currently seeking out the best XPA) or whisky (with a preference for those from Islay). CV9GN9.name: Richard Law
CV9GN9.bio: I currently work for Landcare Research as a hornet-nest-poker and spatial analyst. Current areas of professional interest are structured data and reproducibility, but I also dabble in transportation and economics. I also do freelance web development as [spatialparalysis.xyz](https://spatialparalysis.xyz). I have worked as: a paper-boy for the Evening Post (made redundant age 12); a GIS tutor at Victoria University of Wellington (VUW); a Research Assistant for an economic/public policy think-tank; and, for a few years and until recently I was living in Raglan, working for MetOcean Solutions (now a MetService subsidiary) as a GIS & Web Developer. Now I'm a father and husband before all else. I have a Masters degree in GIS from VUW, and after having written all this I realise you can probably just [find me on LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/richardmlaw/). What LinkedIn won't tell you is that I *really* love [a cup of good, hot, black coffee](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XjkVgc6gIqk).

Current areas of professional interest are structured data and reproducibility, but I also dabble in transportation and economics. RE3QB8.name: Simon Nitz
RE3QB8.bio:
Simon is highly regarded throughout New Zealand as a leader in his field and has also undertaken numerous work in Australia. He has provided over 30+ years of GIS consulting and training services to organisations, focusing on both desktop and web mapping systems. His core strengths are as a GIS System Implementer, GIS Application Developer, GIS Database Administrator, and GIS Project Manager. An acknowledged web mapping technology expert amongst his peers, Simon brings a vast knowledge of not only web mapping technology but also web platforms, desktop GIS Systems and GIS services in general.
Simon regularly runs QGIS training, GeoServer training, PostGIS training, SQL Server training, GeoNode training, Python for GeoSpatial training and Intramaps training through his business Pinpoint Geospatial Solutions.
RE3QB8.shortBio:

He has provided over 30+ years of GIS consulting and training services to organisations, focusing on both desktop and web mapping systems. An acknowledged web mapping technology expert amongst his peers, Simon brings a vast knowledge of not only web mapping technology but also web platforms, desktop GIS Systems and GIS services in general.
Simon regularly runs QGIS training, GeoServer training, PostGIS training, SQL Server training, GeoNode training, Python for GeoSpatial training and Intramaps training through his business Pinpoint Geospatial Solutions.
